Tech Lead is one of the most desirable roles in tech.

The reason?

A good mix of technical and people-related skills, which includes:
- common sense and pragmatism,
- good communication and leadership,
- being a multiplier for others and making everyone around them better.

These skills do well in the AI era and are just going to be more and more important.

To learn how to become a Tech Lead -> join engineers and leads from Meta, Google, IBM, Revolut in my cohort-based course here: https://lnkd.in/exsYfM54 (we start on January 20).

full_text:
AI coding tools are not the problem. The problem is accountability.

It's really important to realize that as an engineer, you need to take ownership of your work and not just blindly open PRs without improving and testing the code to fit the guidelines and desired behavior.

Use AI coding tools, but use them to help you, not to do the work instead of you.

Just opening a PR filled with AI-generated slop is a fast way to lose credibility.

Newsletters are truly an amazing source of knowledge. Here is a list of newsletters that I highly recommend to read:

full_text:
Differences between the Team Lead and the Tech Lead roles.

Team Lead:
- Normally has direct reports
- Facilitates team meetings
- Coaching, mentoring, and delegating work

I like to view this role as doing whatâ€™s best for the team -> If the team lacks technical seniority, you need to fill this gap, and if the team is drowning in tasks, you focus on better prioritization, stakeholder management, or help with finishing the tasks. Itâ€™s certainly a role for good generalists.

Tech Lead:
- Doesn't have direct reports
- Responsible for the technical implementation of the specific project
- Coaching, mentoring, planning, stakeholder management

I like to view this role as a good mix of technical and people-related skills, which includes: common sense and pragmatism, good communication and leadership, being a multiplier for others, and making everyone around them better.

To learn about all the differences between the lead roles, I have just sent out the newsletter to 179k+ engineering leaders called: "Differences Between Lead Roles and How to Find Your Right Path".

Read it here: https://lnkd.in/ejpwCb4Z

full_text:
There are 3 main routes when it comes to Engineering Leadership:
- Management (Team Lead or Engineering Manager)
- IC (Tech Lead or Staff Engineer)
- Architecture (Software Architect)

I consider these to be starting engineering leadership roles, where people in such roles are expected to be multipliers for others and not primarily contributing by finishing assigned tasks.

And these are the skills you need to develop:
- System Design
- Leadership
- Management (for management path)
- Technical details
- Product/Business
- Communication/Influence

The level of depth you need to go in each depends on which path you take.

To help you with this.

Here are 200+ resources to get better at any skills mentioned above: https://lnkd.in/eRMgZ9Ee

full_text:
6 different strategies to become a CTO.

1. Start a company
This is the route of a lot of uncertainty and continuous learning on the job. But the returns on this may be immense.

2. Become a founding engineer
This is especially for someoneÂ who isÂ good at building MVPs.

3. Go through the Management path
The more you grow in the management path, the more you become a good fit for mid+ size companies as a CTO.

4. Go through the Architecture path
This might be a good path for you if you like to still stay in technical details and you love to design great systems. But keep in mind that as a CTO of mid+ size companies, you wonâ€™t be doing that anymore.

5. Go through the IC path
You are a good fit for small-size companies, but you will need to learn the management skills for mid+ size companies.

6. Become a CTO through other roles, mostly Product
Iâ€™ve seen where CTOs come from roles such as DevOps (Head of DevOps), QA (Head of QA), etc. but Iâ€™ve also seen where a CPO or Head of Product transitioned to either a CTPO (Chief Technology and Product Officer) or pure CTO role.

Learn about every strategy in detail here: https://lnkd.in/eFJvcsCi

Donâ€™t screw people. Donâ€™t burn bridges.

Especially if you are in the tech industry, itâ€™s a much smaller world than we may think.

Credibility compounds over time, but it can be lost instantly.

There is no better way to grow than growing together with people who are on a similar path than you.

The path is much more:
- fulfilling,
- faster and
- overall better.

Compete with yourself only and get better every day.

full_text:
I can tell a lot about engineer's seniority by the way they approach solving problems.

Here are 5 indicators that tell me if the engineer has a Senior mindset:

1. They ask all the right questions before they start solving the problem.

2. They REALLY take care of the problem, not just try to quickly patch it and leave it for others to deal with.

3. They focus on simplifying the solution as much as possible.

4. They know when the solution is good enough or when to optimize further.

5. They are self-aware and self-confident enough to admit when they don't know something.

What indicators would you add?

full_text:
Make sure to try to avoid the New Leader Syndrome as an engineer.

What I like to call a â€œNew Leader Syndromeâ€ is when you feel that you need to showcase an extraordinary amount of effort or competence to justify that you deserve to lead that project or team.

And for every individual, it shows up differently:

1. Working extra hours and staying a long time in the office to â€œshowâ€ everyone how great and committed you are

2. Trying to be the best at everything, while also leading the team

3. Always being available and quickly responding to every question

4. Itâ€™s also common for more experienced leaders as well, and it shows when they feel pressured to make quick, visible changes to prove their value

So, this is my advice: When you first step into leadership, itâ€™s common to feel the need to prove yourself by doing more. Extra effort at the beginning is normal, but if you make it unsustainable, thatâ€™s not.

Leadership is not about being perfect or doing everything yourself. Itâ€™s about solving the right problems, setting clear expectations, and enabling others to succeed.

To learn more, read the latest Engineering Leadership article: https://lnkd.in/erHjEY25

full_text:
Coinbase scaled their hiring to 150 engineers per month over the pandemic.

How did they do it?

1. They standardized the searches

Previously, for every new hire, it would be required to draft a â€œjob specâ€. With standardization, you could only hire a frontend engineer, a backend engineer, a crypto engineer, an infra engineer, or an ML engineer (and a few others).

2. They moved from hiring in SF only to nationwide

And later to 10+ countries. This resulted in a massive increase in talent pool size.

3. Interviewing became centralized

Candidates weren't screened by their future hiring manager or peers anymore, but rather by any Coinbase engineer. This massively opened up the interviewer capacity.

4. From hiring manager round-ups to centralized hiring panels

Each day with a rotation, one Coinbase leader would host a hiring panel (with 5-6 senior managers), where all the interview packets feedbacks were reviewed and decided which ones would move to offer and which ones would be rejected.

This gave them the ability to process 40-50 candidates at the pre-offer stage a day.

5. The offers became standardized and non-negotiable

No back and forth with the candidate. Both base salary and equity were directly related to the level you would be hired in, no exceptions allowed.

To learn more, make sure to not miss tomorrow's Engineering Leadership newsletter.

Luca Bonmassar, Former VP of Engineering at Coinbase, is sharing a lot of interesting insights on how they scaled hiring.

To not miss tomorrow's article, make sure to join 180k+ engineering leaders here: https://lnkd.in/eNSKBMUf

full_text:
A lot of CV submissions get dismissed these days, no matter how great your CV is.

Itâ€™s important to find ways to make yourself impossible to be ignored.

This is what I would do if I were looking for a new role as an engineer/engineering leader:

1. Filter out 3-5 roles that fit me well.

2. Contact the hiring manager directly and ask more questions about the role.

3. Share with them a Loom video of a certain suggestion, or improvement that would benefit the org/team. A popular suggestion these days is connected with AI adoption and AI-assisted engineering practices.

4. Submit the application with the CV and let the hiring manager know that youâ€™re looking forward to having a talk with them.

Doing these makes you stand out from others and, importantly, makes it impossible to be ignored.

To learn more, you can read this Engineering Leadership article: https://lnkd.in/eFYsB5pk

full_text:
Differences between the Architect and the Tech Lead roles.

Architect:
- Work across different teams
- Design systems organization-wide,
- Define technology standards and patterns

Tech Lead:
- Part of one team
- Responsible for the technical implementation of the specific project
- Coaching, mentoring, planning, stakeholder management

What I like to say about the Architect role is that you need to think in years and not in sprints. Making good long-term decisions is where your main focus should be.

I normally introduce this role when the tech leads of the team canâ€™t align on the architecture, and where inconsistencies of the implementations tend to happen across different teams.

Both the Tech Lead and the Architect roles usually have no direct reports and rely on influence rather than authority.

To learn more, read the latest Engineering Leadership article here: https://lnkd.in/ejpwCb4Z

full_text:
My top 5 tips to become a great engineering leader in 2026.

1. Make sure to lead in an AI-native world

- For CTOs, VPs, Directors, and Heads of Engineering -> You should own the AI strategy
- For EMs, Architects, Senior+ Engineers -> You should be the one who is setting a good example of what good AI-assisted engineering practices are.

2. Build your network outside of your company

It has increasingly become important for engineering leaders to be able to manage expectations well, especially when it comes to AI tools or adopting AI in general.

If you want to manage expectations well, you need to know and understand what tools other organizations use and why they use them. And the best way to do that is to have people in your network that you can talk to outside of your current company.

3. Become better at communication and/or tech skills

Both are going to be more and more important, especially stakeholder communication, which is becoming increasingly harder now that AI is involved in the process, and at the same time, you canâ€™t do AI-assisted engineering well if your tech skills are not at a good level.

4. Building the right things is more important than ever

Thatâ€™s another important aspect that you need to put a lot of focus on. When your team can be more productive, it becomes even more crucial that the productivity is moved in the right direction.

5. Invest in your own sustainability

The role of engineering leaders is increasingly becoming more demanding and more stressful than it was some time ago. So, make sure to realize the following -> burned-out leaders create burned-out teams.

You need to ensure that your work is sustainable for the long run and not just for the short sprint.

To learn more, read the full Engineering Leadership article here: https://lnkd.in/eQNtVyzt

Leadership isnâ€™t always about being in the front seat.

Sometimes, the most effective move is to step back.

When you do, you create space for someone on your team to step up, take ownership, and grow. At the same time, you free yourself to focus on higher-level, strategic work.

The result?
- You become a stronger leader
- Create a more capable team
- You create leaders

A win-win-win.

Read this Engineering Leadership article to learn how great engineering leaders create leaders: https://lnkd.in/eMcmNuR8

When I was a Senior Software Engineer, I felt stuck.

I was overthinking about my career path, and I didnâ€™t know which particular skills I should focus on:
- â€œWhat is going to be that next step for me?â€
- â€œShould I go into management, architecture, or should I grow as an IC?â€
- â€œWhat particular skills should I be learning next?â€

These questions were always on my mind.

My growth was stagnating because I wasnâ€™t intentional about my growth, and I didn't have defined goals.

And that's where we, as engineering leaders, should help as much as possible. To help our people define their growth goals.

How to help?

Make sure to read the latest Engineering Leadership article called: How to Help Engineers Define Their Growth Goals here: https://lnkd.in/efQJSR2r

full_text:
When people feel like they are growing, thatâ€™s when they feel the most motivated.

This is really important to understand as an engineering leader, because you are playing a big part in defining the overall culture inside your team and also in your organization.

And it all starts with the clarity of defining goals for your people.

- Do they want to become a Staff Engineer, an Architect, or a Manager? 
- Are they happy where they are at the moment and wish to grow by learning a new skill? 
- What does growth actually mean for them?

Those are all very important questions that, as leaders, we should definitely help our engineers find answers to!

How to do that, you may ask? 

To help us with this, in tomorrow's Engineering Leadership newsletter, Simone D'Amico will be sharing a LOT of tips on how to do that.

full_text:
Switching off from work is a skill like any other. Make sure to practice it over the holidays.

Especially if you are an engineering leader, it's really important to switch off regularly. Always keep in mind that as an engineering leader, you are setting an example.

If you work:
- Long hours, weekends, over the holidays
- You always respond to Slack messages fast, even at unusual times
- You send emails overnight, etc.

You are setting an example and expectations for your whole team.

The whole team feels like they need to do the same, or else they might feel that they are not doing the work up to the expectations.

Which ultimately can lead people to burn out, while they are doing great work â†’ all because of misaligned expectations.

Switching off wonâ€™t make you less committed. It makes you more sustainable, and it will make your team stronger, because it gives room to others to step up when youâ€™re not there.

It will also allow you to enjoy the career youâ€™re working so hard to build.

Learn more in the latest article: https://lnkd.in/eegZKbrs

Wish you a happy and successful New Year 2026!

What 2025 taught me about Engineering Leadership.

Itâ€™s Christmas Eve today ðŸŽ„, and many of you are celebrating Christmas and enjoying the holidays, me included :) I always like to use this time to reflect, recharge, and prepare for a successful upcoming year!

In today's article on my newsletter Engineering Leadership, I am sharing the 5 most important lessons and findings impacting engineering & engineering leadership this year.

These lessons/findings are:

1. The narrative â€œAI is replacing software engineersâ€ is simply not true

2. The negative perception of AI was caused by sensationalistic takes from well-known public individuals

3. Managing expectations has become THE job for engineering leaders

4. The roles are getting closer together

5. Being a multiplier is a must in the AI-era

Read all these lessons/findings in detail in the article I just sent out to 177k+ engineering leaders here: https://lnkd.in/ekNpgs6P

full_text:
My top 5 tips for AI-assisted engineering:

1. Make sure to take full accountability and ownership

Treat all AI-generated code as your own responsibility. Test it, review it, and make sure that you completely understand it before submitting. It should never happen that you submit a line of code without knowing what it actually does.

2. Use AI as a thought partner, and not just blindly trust

Donâ€™t use AI on autopilot, treat it like a co-pilot instead. Ask to explain concepts, generate boilerplate, or explore solutions, but never let it replace your role in critical thinking, system design, or architectural decisions.

Your pragmatism, intuition, domain knowledge, and ability to evaluate trade-offs are irreplaceable.

3. Prioritize understanding over speed

Focusing purely on faster delivery can be dangerous if it comes at the cost of a lack of understanding. Your workflow should never look like â€œcopy-paste and prayâ€.

Take the time to review and internalize what the LLM generates.

4. There should always be a person responsible, full automation is not a reality in AI-assisted engineering

Donâ€™t aim for full automation. AI in software development should always include human oversight, especially in critical systems.

From planning and design through to implementation and testing, there should always be a real engineer making the final call.

5. AI amplifies existing practices, so make sure to focus on developing them

This is really important to understand: â€œAI tools amplify what you already do.â€
If you know how to build the right way, AI boosts your productivity. If not, it magnifies bad habits.

To learn more, read my latest article: https://lnkd.in/eQprBmQh

full_text:
The mistake engineers make when working with AI coding tools.

What I am seeing and also hearing happening regularly, especially with less experienced engineers, is the following:

1. They are assigned a task, and they use a certain AI coding tool, use their agent mode to finish the task.

2. They donâ€™t go the extra mile to actually understand what has been changed and ensure the changes are made within the guidelines of the codebase.

3. They open the PR.

And because they didnâ€™t REALLY take ownership and ensure they are delivering good quality code, this puts a lot of pressure on reviewers to find all the mistakes and completely shifts the work on them.

There may be a lot of comments on PRs, and it takes a lot of time to review correctly.

And even in some cases, engineers give up and just approve the PR, which makes things a lot worse in the long run.

Crucial thing to understand here is that AI is like any other tool, and itâ€™s here to help us, not to shift the accountability from the person submitting a PR to AI, which should NEVER happen.

Always take ownership and accountability for your actions and decisions, and don't blame AI for the output that YOU used.

To learn more, yesterday, I sent out the article to 176k+ engineering leaders on this topic. Read the full article: https://lnkd.in/eQprBmQh

full_text:
How to start with public speaking as an engineer or engineering leader?

Giving talks at events and conferences has really been one of the most rewarding things for me.

It feels great when you get to share knowledge, and people learn something new that helps them to become a better engineer or engineering leader.

But not just that, you get to learn new things as well, because when you are preparing to give a talk, you are cementing your knowledge on that topic.

This is my advice on how to get started:

1. Start looking for opportunities to share knowledge across your organization

This should be the first thing you focus on if you don't already, and you can start really small. No need to volunteer for presenting across the whole organization right from the jump. Remember that small steps eventually lead to big results.

2. Present at a local meetup

After you share your knowledge internally, look to share it with other people as well, outside of your org. Presenting at a local meetup is a great way to gain experience speaking in a low-stakes situation. Everyone is there to learn and have a good time.

3. Start applying to present at a conference

After you get experience at a local meetup, you should start applying for talks at conferences. It is important to mention that you donâ€™t need to be an all-time amazing public speaker to have a talk. In our industry, the substance is the most important thing, not that you have 10/10 public speaking skills.

To learn more, read my latest article: https://lnkd.in/eGH53DqJ

Engineers must become multipliers in the AI-era.

The reason?

As tools for development have gotten better, the desired skills for engineers have moved from just pure knowing programming languages and frameworks (expected) to problem-solving abilities and people skills.

But what does it actually mean to be an engineering multiplier?

Being an engineering multiplier means being someone who amplifies the productivity and effectiveness of the engineers around them, not just focusing on their own output, but elevating the entire team.

An engineering multiplier doesnâ€™t just ask, â€œWhat can I build?â€, they ask, â€œHow can I make everyone around me more effective?â€.

And this is what multipliers are doing. They are:
- Improving team efficiency
- Sharing knowledge
- Raising the quality bar
- Enabling better decisions
- Mentoring and empowering others

full_text:
This is how I do a full engineering org audit.

As a Fractional CTO and advisor, one of the common things that I did a couple of times this year was an engineering organizational audit.

I use the same approach as I would use in the first 90 days if I were to start a new full-time engineering leadership role.

1. The first thing I do is to really understand the pain points
In some cases, they have secured new funding and would like to scale and focus on hiring. Another reason may be that the CTO has left the company, and they would like to do a good overview of the current org before making any decisions.

2. The second thing I do is have 1:1s with the relevant people
The 3 main questions I normally ask here are:
- How are you feeling about your current work and projects?
- What do you believe is going well, and what could be improved?
- How can I support and help you?

3. Following, I go through all the relevant parts of the engineering org
I normally combine the second and this step together, as I am able to ask much better questions if I understand certain parts much better. I go through the documentation, check the codebase, overall architecture, and also assess all of the different parts:
- Hiring
- Culture
- Continuous growth
- Knowledge sharing
- Planning and alignment
- Onboarding process
- Release process
- Development process
- Incident management process
- Security

4. Provide suggestions for improvements and present the findings
I make sure I note all the important info in the board and finish by providing my suggestions for improvements. After I have everything prepared, I present my findings together with my suggestions.

To learn more, read my latest article: https://lnkd.in/e35MCdPx

Included in the article:
ðŸŽ Checklist For a Great Engineering Organization
ðŸŽ Board For a Great Engineering Organization

full_text:
What do I look for in a Senior Software Engineer as a manager?

There are so many different things that make a senior engineer. If I can sum all of them in 1 sentence, that would be:

A senior engineer should be able to independently understand the problem and find the right solution to it.

I am not just talking about technical solutions here. I mean solutions across different areas including communication, collaboration, mentoring and helping others.

And by no means do I mean that you need to have the right answers on the spot. A senior engineer is able to find and gather solutions from various of different sources.

Software engineering is too broad of a field to be an expert in everything or to know everything upfront.

As a manager, I wish to rely on a senior to make good decisions, do the right things and inspire others to do the same.

Learn more how to become a Senior Software Engineer here: https://lnkd.in/dUeAbHqD

full_text:
This is what I would do if I would be looking for a new engineering/engineering leadership role.

1. First, I would make sure that my CV is on point
It's the first impression that a hiring manager gets of you, and you must leave a good one.

2. Ensure that my LinkedIn profile is updated and optimized
Personally, LinkedIn has been huge for my career, as almost all the roles I've gotten have come through it. Either people contacted me directly, referred me, or I applied to a specific role.

3. Find 3-5 roles that fit with what I would be looking for
The reason for this is that the strategy called â€œspray and prayâ€, where you just send infinite CVs to infinite companies, normally doesnâ€™t work so well, as companies receive a LOT of submissions.

4. Find the hiring manager or recruiter responsible for the role on LinkedIn
I would contact that person through LinkedIn and ask them a few questions about the role. Something that would be interesting for me to know and that would give me a better overview of what I can expect.

5. I would try to stand out in this step already
I would record a video, it would be a Loom video or something else, where I would share improvements (suggestions) to the product or service related to the company I am applying to. I would submit my CV and send the hiring manager the video.

Even though this takes more time, especially if you are doing this for 3-5 companies, itâ€™s a LOT better approach than just sending CVs and hoping for the best.

Doing this will make it impossible for a hiring manager to ignore you.

To learn more, read my latest article titled "My Advice For Engineers and Engineering Leaders to Get a New Role Faster" here: https://lnkd.in/eFYsB5pk

full_text:
Set up your next 3 years for success in 5 minutes with this one simple tip.

Make a PLAN! It's one of the best ways to grow faster in your career. Winging it doesn't always work, who knew ðŸ˜….

Well, thanks to our first contributors, we have a brand new Career Growth Plan Template added to our template library. Huge shoutout to Gregor Ojstersek and Omar Halabieh for sharing it publicly ðŸ‘

Effective plans always work backward from the goal, which is why I love this template. Here's how it works in 3 steps.

1. Define your long-term vision. Where do you see yourself in the next 3-5 years?
2. Define short and medium-term objectives that will help you work toward that
3. In the table, jot down areas you need to grow to achieve those, using SMART goals.

That's it! Now you have your plan. Start working on those goals, check in every few months, and update as needed.

Check out the full template here: https://lnkd.in/eiY_vqZ3 

There's also 18 free templates in our template library. Check them out and use as needed!

full_text:
My advice for engineers looking for new roles (especially with less experience).

Try to look for unfair advantage when applying to roles or when you are already in the hiring process.

After my first two student jobs as an engineer, I started to apply for my first full-time engineering position.

I applied to the role that I liked and the first interview went well. I was invited to the second interview.

Before that interview, I designed + coded a new website for them. I designed it with Photoshop and built it with HTML + CSS + JS and a bit of PHP.

They liked it and gave me good feedback.

The next day, I received an email where they offered me the position, which wouldn't happen if I didn't do that. I was ecstatic.

You can see how the site looked like in the picture below.

So, my advice is:
Try to do something to stand out when you apply to the role or when you are already in the hiring process.

Try to look for that unfair advantage that will differentiate you from other candidates.

In tomorrow's newsletter, I'll be sharing more tips and advice on how to be successful in getting a new role as an engineer or engineering leader.

Make sure to not miss it and join 174k+ engineering leaders here: https://lnkd.in/eNSKBMUf
